Environmental Best Management Practices

12 Environmental Rules for Working at the Esquimalt Graving Dock

Refer to the Esquimalt Graving Dock Environmental Best Management Practices Manual for more detailed information on best management practices and applicable environmental regulations.

Vessel Maintenance While Drydocked

  1. Sandblasting activities must be enclosed to prevent escaping air emissions from impacting workers, neighbours and the environment.
  2. Pressure washwater containing paint contaminants must be prevented from entering the harbour.
  3. Spills must be immediately cleaned up and reported. Spill response material must be easily accessible, and personnel must be trained in its use.
  4. Oils, sandblasting grit and paint, which accumulate in work areas, must be prevented from entering the tunnels below the drydock or storm drains leading to the harbour.
  5. Non-contaminated water (i.e. ballast water, cooling water) must be directed away from contaminants on the dock floor or work areas. Debris, including grit and paint waste, must be cleaned up to prevent rainwater from washing contaminants into tunnels and drains.
  6. The drydock floor, sills and ditches must be cleaned up of all debris prior to flooding.

Vessels Berthed at the Wharves or Jetties

  1. No abrasive blasting, scaling, welding, grinding or painting will be permitted unless debris or emissions can be controlled and prevented from entering the water.
  2. Fuelling of vessels must be done in accordance with the Canada Shipping Act-Oil Pollution Prevention Regulations. This includes meeting the requirements for proper conduits/connections, two way communication, and spill response planning and capability.
  3. Black water, grey water, or super-chlorinated water which has been neutralized, must be discharged into the sanitary sewer system through designated discharge points at the facility, and must meet the requirements outlined in the Capital Regional District Sanitary Sewer Bylaw and Ship and Boat Waste Disposal Facility Authorization.

General Site Requirements

  1. Store hazardous materials (including paints, oils, solvents, acids, etc) in appropriate containers, in designated areas, and well away from drains to the harbour.
  2. Ensure that all containers that are not stored in a permanent storage area are labelled in legible English with the contents and the company responsible for material while at the facility.
  3. Ensure that garbage and recycling containers are placed in leased areas, lunchrooms and work areas. Employees and subcontractors must be made aware that all garbage, such as earplugs, dust masks and Styrofoam cups, must placed in appropriate disposal containers.
